column5: I have never used a developer forum

column6: Stack Overflow and other Stack Exchange subprojects
column8: When it's in line with mine it makes it stronger. When it's not, it forces me to analyse arguments provided.
column9: Usually I use google (external) search and just prefer links to known forums over others.
column10: Lack of answers, low quality answers (no reasoning)
column11: Explanation and arguments that I can verify, links to authoritative sources
column15: Applicability to my problem, maturity, whether it evolves and is supported, code quality
column16: Merging duplicates is essential for Stack Exchange forums
column31: Two or three times a week

column8:
– Learning from others’ experience to save time and pick the right tool
– Compensating for lacking “official” documentation to save time finding out how to use the tool
column9:
— Searching using a general-purpose search engine (Google, DuckDuckGo), and following links in result listings
— StackOverflow: opening noted author’s personal profile and looking at other questions they answered or asked
column10: Ensuring that the information is up-to-date and accurate requires going back-and-forth between forums and software project’s “official” docs to ensure accuracy (in this case official docs would be lacking, hence using forums in the first place).
column11: Provided reasoning, author’s reputation, phrasing, absence of errors in spelling/grammar/punctuation
column15: Documentation quality, reliability, careful execution of breaking changes, depending on domain specific factors can become relevant (speed, flexibility)
column16: No obvious way to summarize opinions while preserving the critical context, including post author’s reputation and experience, etc.
column30: Developer forums (e.g., Stack Overflow);General-purpose search engine, Friends and acquaintances
column31: Two or three times a week

column8:
- other developers sometimes more experienced in a specific area
- possibility to reach out to the developers of the APIs
- higher possibility to find a solution to a specifc problem
- possibility to get an answer to a specific question (which may not be explained in other sources like the API's documentation)
column9: Either via a search provider or via the internal search mechanism of the forum. On multiple posts I go from the topmost one down by either opening them in new browser tabs or by using the browser history to go back to the list after reading a post.
column10:
- poor search mechanisms
- having a too broad or too specific question to get a proper answer
- reading through the irrelevant suggestions to find the one that fits to your problem
column11:
- working, concise example code
- explanation of what the API does exactly (at best incl. several inline comments in the code)
- additional reference links
column15:
- selfexplaining names
- concise syntax
- customizability through parameters with proper default values
column16:
- reading through each post
- voting systems (like on Stack Overflow)
- flagging systems (like on Stack Overflow)
column17:
- easier spotting of the most commonly used API
- filtering out inappropriate reviews
column18: - other reviews, which may fit better to a specific use case, might be filtered out
column30: Developer forums (e.g., Stack Overflow);Internal Mailing list;Co-workers;(online) documentations
column31: Two or three times a week

column6: Stack Overflow (and other Stack Excange sites)
column8: Software Documentation is tricky, and often outdated. Forums give you a view from "down in the trenches"
column9: Search for a specific problem, targeting specific tags
column10: usually special characters like (){}!@#$%^&* are unsearchable
column11: Commentary, votes, and if it makes sense with regard to my experience
column16: Often there are links to blog posts offering direct comparisons of APIs or other frameworks.
column17: You can see how the code _really_ works, as opposed to how the documentation _thinks_ it works
column18: The documentation becomes unreliable, which isn't good for the company providing it.
column31: Two or three times a week

column10: Finding someone else that has done the same thing before me and benefiting from their knowledge
column11: Grammar, spelling, formatting, accuracy, completeness, examples
